title: Callum Hawkins suffers fresh fourth place heartbreak in midnight marathon tilt
text:

Callum Hawkins, who prepared for the World Championships marathon by training in his garden shed with a bank of Aldi heaters to replicate the heat and humidity of Qatar, came within a whisker of a medal in the early hours.

A heroic attempt by the Scot to improve on his fourth placed finish in London two years ago saw him lead a mile from the finish, only to slip back and again finish one place outside the medals.

“At two laps to go I felt great so I just kept pushing and pushing,” said the Scot, who collapsed in the heat when leading the Commonwealth Games marathon in Australia 18 months ago.

(Image: Mike Egerton/PA Wire)

“And then when I caught them I knew I didn’t have a kick, I was just trying to be strong. That’s why as soon as I got to them, I hit the front and tried to burn them off. But they were just waiting for the kick.

“I knew this was the pace I’d got and I was trying everything to lift it but I just couldn’t. To be even closer than last time, it’s gutting. I really wanted that medal and that’s what I trained for. But it wasn’t to be on the night.”

Hawkins, 27, had shown how serious he was about getting a medal by training in up to 39 degrees in his shed.

(Image: Getty)

In the event the heat and humidity was not quite as brutally punishing as it had been for the majority of these championships.

He ran a superb race, giving the African favourites the fright of their lives, before stopping the clock on 2:10.57.

Lelisa Desisa, finishing just 17 seconds ahead the Scottish braveheart, headed an Ethiopian one-two, with Mosinet Geremew second and Amos Kipruto of Kenya third.
